case_vignette: A 62-year-old African American man presents to establish care and to undergo skin examination, which he reports receiving regularly since his sister was diagnosed with melanoma. Examination reveals 3-mm hyperpigmented horizontal bands across the nailbeds of all fingernails, which he reports have been present since his 20s. He denies experiencing any other nail changes or pain. He takes no medications, and he has no history of skin cancer or suspicious moles. He has no relevant medical history.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Melanonychia is not cancerous and does not typically cause any pain or other symptoms. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including:

1. Genetics: Melanonychia can be inherited from one's parents.
2. Hormonal changes: Hormonal fluctuations during pregnancy, menstruation, or menopause can cause melanonychia.
3. Skin conditions: Certain skin conditions, such as psoriasis or eczema, can cause melanonychia.
4. Nutritional deficiencies: Deficiencies in nutrients such as vitamin B12 or iron can cause melanonychia.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've come in for a regular skin check and while I don't have any symptoms, I've noticed that there are dark stripes across all of my fingernails that have been there since my 20s.

No, I haven't noticed any changes in the color or shape of my nails over time, and no, I haven't had any recent exposure to chemicals or substances that could cause the discoloration.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to perform a quick physical examination of your nails. Can you please show me your fingernails and toenails for a moment? (Please note: I will not physically examine the patient, this is just a virtual consultation)
Sure, you can look at my fingernails; they have dark stripes across them, but I haven't noticed anything unusual with my toenails.

Great, thank you for showing me your fingernails. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of the dark stripes on your nails.

Can you tell me, have you noticed any other symptoms such as discoloration or thickening of the skin on your fingers or toes? And have you had any recent infections or illnesses?
No, I haven't noticed any discoloration or thickening of the skin on my fingers or toes, and I haven't had any recent infections or illnesses.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider a few potential causes of the dark stripes on your nails. Can you tell me, have you ever had a fungal infection or any other type of infection that could cause discoloration of the nails?
No, I've never had a fungal infection or any other type of infection that could cause discoloration of the nails.

Okay, that helps to narrow it down. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of a condition called "trachycaries." It is a rare condition that causes dark stripes to appear on the nails, usually on the fingernails. It is caused by a genetic mutation and can run in families. Have you ever heard of trachycaries or have any family members with this condition?
No, I've never heard of trachycaries and I don't know of any family members with this condition.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to make a diagnosis of trachycaries. This condition is caused by a genetic mutation that affects the growth of the nails, resulting in dark stripes or bands on the nails. It is a relatively rare condition and can be inherited from one's parents.

I recommend that you consult with a dermatologist or a nail specialist for further evaluation and treatment. They will be able to confirm the diagnosis and provide appropriate treatment options. In the meantime, you can try using a nail brush to gently clean the nails and remove any dirt or debris that may be contributing to the discoloration.

Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.
